title: Do you need music theory to produce music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Definitely not. I know lots of producers who have both gone to school for theory and music production, and many who haven’t done either. They’re all pretty decent. If you’re looking for someone to work with, find someone that works with you, is excited to work with you, and understands your style of playing and recording. Some people can just ‘get’ production, while others need the theory as foundation. As well, it makes a difference as to who the producer is working with. If it’s musicians in a band, it’s easy to just say “play that again with more juice” versus recording classical musicians who want/need specific instructions like “play that Bm7 to F bar in staccato.” Still, I’ve worked with some people who can explain to classically trained artists what they need to do, simply, and without theory. All in all - it will never hurt you to have some knowledge of musical theory - but there are successful producers who don’t.

Short answer: No, you don’t need to know music theory to make good music. Some people just understand how to make music work without knowing actual music theory. Long answer: Not necessarily, although it depends on the kind of music you want to make. I am a musician and although I do know music theory, I don’t typically use it to come up with things. Once you’ve played music for awhile, you sort of just know what sounds good. If you’re just trying to create something cool and fun, especially with today’s music, you can get away with pretty much anything. If you were trying to make an homage to Bach or something like that, yes, you should know music theory so that you can understand what they were doing and how they were doing it, but even then I wouldn’t say you need to know it because some people can just hear specific patterns or tendencies in music and can replicate them without actually knowing what was happening on the page of written music. It’s very much dependent on the person making the music.

I am so sick of music theory questions and I was so happy so many of the answers say NO. That is the correct answer. Take any of the greatest artist and even some of the producers from the years before the 90’s and many or even most I dare say have any music theory education and yet they produced some of the greatest music ever. Some like George Martin who most likely understood music theory all too well just tossed it out the window when working with the Beatles because they flew in the face of music theory and broke just about every rule on their way to becoming the greatest band of all time. I have been writing songs, performing and even producing music for many years and I never studied music theory nor could I care less in ever learning. Those who can make music and those who can’t study music theory and criticize those of us who actually make music.

For pop/rock/country, no. But you still have to work your ass off and have plenty of talent. If you do, you’ll eventually absorb the“theory” you need.And if you do understand theory, it will make your life easier and give you more choices. 2) For classical, jazz, film scoring, arranging and orchestration and lots of other music professions, YES. Damn right. You’ll get nowhere without theory knowledge of various musical types. Don’t worry! It won’t hurt a bit! It’s fun to know what the hell you've doing. Learn the rules so you can break them. That’s art!

A lot of people claim to know no theory, but they do, in fact, know some theory. They may not have the vocabulary of a jazz musician, but they certainly know some. Simple examples: If you play a progression of Am, C, G, Em, you are using your knowledge of music to create an oft-used progression. This is not only theory, but an application of theory. There are zero successful musicians since the time before Bach that doesn’t know the above progression along with myriad other simple progressions. A drummer knows to count to 4. Once again, there are zero drummers in the entire history of music who don’t know this fundamental truth of rhythm. Do you, who plans to work with musicians, really want guys “who know no theory” to look at you like a moron for not even knowing the basics? Of course not. So, yes, learn some theory. You don’t have to be jazz-level theory, but you have to at least know the basic.

In the most basic terms, no, you do not need music theory to produce music. But theory is one of the most useful things you can learn if you want to produce music to the best of your ability. It’s also necessary if you ever plan to talk to and work with other trained musicians, composers, arrangers or producers. Learning simple theory is one of the most useful things you can do as a music producer. Knowing the building blocks of music will allow you to make music with more intention, and take your music further than just “what sounds cool”. Music theory has been developed over hundreds of years and is still developing, and there is a reason that music students undergo rigorous music theory and analysis courses. Can you have a conversation with someone who speaks a different language? Maybe you can get a general idea across, but the conversation would be much more interesting and effective if you learned their language. Music is the same way. If you ever plan to effectively communicate your ideas to others in the music industry, music theory is an essential tool you should learn in order to be understood and, ultimately, taken seriously in the industry.

I think it depends upon the genre you are working in. Everyone would probably agree that Paul McCartney wrote good pop tunes yet was illiterate in theory. However, when latterly he decided to turn his hand to classical music, he lacked the requisite theoretical knowledge and expertise. Therefore, he engaged professional classical musicians such as Carl Davis and the late Richard Rodney Bennett to assist him. Classical music is historically theoretically conceived through the medium of staff notation. That makes it innately more complex because more intellectual processes are involved in that conception.

NO you do not. Many producers and artists never formally learn it ever. But it is good to have theories. And if you don’t want to I would suggest studying just a bit of sound theory - this stuff is simpler and fantastic… Where it really helps it when trying to discuss what you are trying to do with other artists and producers.

It's not a requirement as the primary job function of a Producer is to oversee and direct the recording process of a song created to its final mix stage. Some Producer's are hands on in the Songwriting and Arranging process, while some are technical producers that are also engineers while some are completely hands of as strickly creative directors. If you are heavily involved in Vocal Arranging, Composing, and Arranging the composition I strongly recommand picking up some music theory because it helps you analayize each section of song when arranging. Understanding harmonic relationships is very important. Vetern Record Producer Ron Fair is similar to Quincy Jones that not only has a great ear but a strong music theory background as he's very good at Arranging for strings and vocal arranging.

No. But then, you only need 3 or 4 chords to write a hit song. Your chances of actually being a good musician go up a lot if you do. One of my favorite stories is about an interview with the wild bass-man for Van Halen. The interviewer first showed a clip from a recent concert, which showed the bassist doing a very complicated bass solo, sitting alone on a chair in front of the audience, one-handed, while up-ending a jug of whiskey onto his face as the crowd erupted into cheers. The camera panned back to show the studio, and the interviewer chippie asked, “WHERE did you learn to play the bass like THAT!” Then the camera dollies in to a close-up of the bassist’s face smiling hugely as he intoned,”Jew’-lee-ards!” The wildest, most esoteric, least-establishment type of playing starts out with a firm grounding in the basics. Good music is work. Great music is all of that plus inspiration. It doesn’t start with the inspiration, but with the perspiration. “You must study very hard.”

There are one hundred and one famous musical geniuses in pop, rock, R&B, and jazz that know nothing about music theory. Unfortunately, most of us aren’t musical geniuses. As a guitar teacher, I don’t mention the term “music theory” because it causes the glass eye, roll back in your head syndrome. I start introducing music theory in small bites, gently mixed with the song the student is interested in learning. By the time they know it, they are using music theory concepts without even realizing it. Music is meant to be fun and an emotional expression and I try to keep it that way.

The thing is that some people innately understand the rules that are codified in formal music theory. Frank Sinatra never learned to read music but his feel for music was amazing. He didn’t need to learn because he a) had an innate understanding and b) worked with the best who did know the theory. Even this though simplifies as I am very confident that Sinatra worked very hard on improving his abilities which means that whether he read a book on being a better singer or listened to great singers (in the hall or off a recording) he was learning theory. Theory is merely ways of expressing what works and why. I have a few of my own ways of expressing music theory (with fewer dots and no mention of a circle of fifths!!!!!!!): Scene & Story expressed as Tone over Time.

response.answer_text: If I understand the job of a music producer, then the answer is no, of course not. Long ago there were “A&R men”, meaning Artist and Repertoire. Meaning matching a specific song to a specific talent. If music producer is what was called an A&R person, then no, music theory and indeed college itself is superfluous; if that is what a music producer is.

No. If this was true, there would have been no folk music over the centuries and very little rock and roll. If you do understand music theory, it may allow you to work at another level with others who share this knowledge and create music of greater complexity more quickly. for what it’s worth,d

Negative. EDM has a long list of successful music producers who brag about not knowing any formal music theory, yet still make killer tracks. That being said, having been on both sides of the debate I will say this: It’s easy to break the rules once you know them. I find for my own productions music theory allows me to quickly create the ideas I have in my head. Before music theory I could still create them, it just took a lot longer.

response.answer_text: No, but usually if the music is good you’ll find it to be theoretically sound. The only exception would be ambient music which can stand on its own without any theory. There could be a mid-point which uses some theory which serves to enhance the music without using it to any large degree.
You don’t strictly need it, but it certainly helps. Especially when you don’t want to work completely solitary, as music theory tends to give you names for things that make communication easier.
